press.quote: We Could Stay, the Brooklyn electronic musician’s staggering debut, artfully oscillates between moments of hypnotic bliss and jarring violence...each track is a full journey, Wagner gleefully bending dance music tropes into unpredictable shapes. Inspect his wall of sound a little closer, and you’ll discover the thunderous roar cleverly hiding a pop sensibility...We Could Stay is breathlessly thrilling—bruised, beautiful, and completely engulfing.
The ghostly vocal samples on 'Never Gone' bubble up so gently, it’s hard to tell if they’re actually there or if your brain’s working to make sense of the song’s cacophonous, shoegazing frequencies.
...an impressive build-up of pounding percussion and pulsating ambience, culminating in a whirlwind of thunderous sounds and euphoric voices.

releases.title: Release Yrself
releases.coverArtist: Cover art by Casey Fletcher and Studio Sparks

press.quote: Suddenly, it’s upon you: An enormous four-chord vamp mangled by distortion and haunted vocal echoes, the song’s shimmering chimes playing around the edges. There’s a seductive elegance to the track’s destruction, like spending your final moments caught in a tornado, marveling at its power. In its last quarter, the noisy layers of 'Release Yrself' fall away, leaving the softly glowing embers of a lullaby-like melody. Right when it feels light enough to drift off on the breeze, Wagner brings in a startling, stabbing trance synth, caking it with the blistering overdrive of a tape deck eating itself.
It’s all there. The emotion, mangled samples, driving house beat, destroyed ending. Lovely work.

PYNKIE’s new release, Songies, blends twee, soft shoegaze, and a sharp indie-pop sensibility...some of 2023’s best moments thus far...PYNKIE certainly wears her laid-back influences on her sleeve. Yet, take an extended dive into her new record, and one discovers a creative, downright exciting intensity bursting from all the songs on Songies... This mature, intelligently constructed indie pop has some of 2023’s finest moments...Give this wonderful, catchy record a listen, and we promise at least three sequences that will immediately whet your ears for more.

Songies delivers a variety of meaning through Radice's lyricism as the storytelling touches upon breakups, self-honesty, and the perspectives of time and space...The love and care PYNKIE contributes to her art is clear, assuring you to become an instant fan. It is safe to expect her to continue gaining traction through her originality and vocal ability, uplifting listeners during darker times.

releases.title: It Is Lighter Than You Think
releases.coverArtist: Cover art by Carrie and Matt Wagner

press.quote: [Their sophomore record] explodes their horizons outward, encompassing a constantly-shifting expanse of genres and showcasing an impressive refusal to limit their sound to any one direction.

‘Roman Candle Part II’ is a sonic companion for the lonely, a friend for those losing hope and a song that is endlessly replayable. With its nostalgic point towards 90s triphop combined with sublime minimal electronica sensibilities, its brooding reverb blanket, shifting dance-infused beats and a vocal which summons you into a dream-like state, this is without question one of the finest tracks of the year so far. Drawing surprising emotion clout, its haunting melodies and heavenly ambiance is nothing short of divine. Drink it all in.
I have to say...I heard that song and I was like...This is great. This is my Lost in Translation soundtrack moment.
...it possesses a timelessness that I've craved in recent indie electronic music.

'Microwave S’mores'...is tailor-made for your next wistful stare out the window. The dreamy track ebbs and flows between lilting guitars and ethereal vocals up to bursts of heavy shoegaze-style TV static making for a delightfully mind-bending listening experience.

Silver Liz has the uncanny ability to produce lush, fuzzed out indie pop that is both gritty and sensitive. Their latest single is also timely, diving into the pros and cons of being an introvert in modern society.

An album that’s filled to the brim with longing anthems, Silver Liz’s I Can Feel the Weight provides instant feels upon pressing play. It’s a washed out affair, whether they’re bringing in crashing, bent waves of distortion, pattering synth arpeggios, wind-riding guitar smears or ethereal vocals. It all floats in a sprawling expanse of stars, anchored back by a distinctive indie pop sensibility. Proof that when quality songwriting and quality atmospherics smash together, you’ll find some magic.
...shimmering guitars, hazy phased-sounding cymbals and layers of treated vocals.  This is psychedelia, but psychedelia given an electronic makeover, an entirely modern sound.
